text: Solve this problem step by step.
End with 'DONE.' when you have a solution.
Question: A man lives in a small apartment on the 30th floor of a high-rise building.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
In the evening, when he returns, he takes the elevator to the 15th floor and then walks up the stairs for the remaining 15 floors to his apartment.
However, on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way up to the 30th floor.

Why does he do this? 

 Solution: 
<think>
Okay, so I'm trying to figure out why this man takes the elevator all the way up to the 30th floor on rainy days.
Let me break down the problem step by step.
First, let's understand his daily routine.
Every morning, he takes the elevator from the 30th floor down to the ground floor (which is floor 1) to go to work.
In the evening, when he returns, he takes the elevator up to the 15th floor and then walks up the remaining 15 floors to his apartment on the 30th floor.
But on rainy days, he changes his routine and takes the elevator all the way up to the 30th floor instead of walking up after the elevator stops at the 15th floor.
I need to find out why this difference occurs specifically on rainy days.
Let me think about the possible reasons.
One possibility is that walking up the stairs is uncomfortable or time-consuming, especially in bad weather.
Rainy days can make walking up stairs slippery and uncomfortable, so maybe he avoids that by taking the elevator all the way.
That makes sense because on rainy days, walking up 15 floors could be messy and unsafe.
Another angle could be the time factor.
Maybe the elevator is faster, but that doesn't seem likely because the elevator stops at the 15th floor on normal days, so it's not about speed.
It's more about the action of walking in the rain.
Wait, perhaps there's something about the elevator's timing or availability.
Maybe on rainy days, the elevator is more frequently used, so he doesn't have to wait as long or it's more reliable.
But that might be a stretch because the problem doesn't mention anything about elevator reliability changing with weather.
Another thought: maybe he's trying to avoid getting his clothes wet.
Walking up 15 floors in the rain could mean he'd be exposed to the rain more, especially if he's wearing certain clothes or if it's a heavy downpour.
Taking the elevator all the way would keep him dry.
Also, perhaps the building's design or the elevator's programming has a role.
Maybe on rainy days, the elevator doesn't stop at certain floors, or it's programmed differently.
But that's probably not the case because the problem doesn't mention any changes in the elevator's behavior except on rainy days.
Wait, maybe it's about the effort involved.
Walking up 15 floors might be physically taxing, especially after a long day at work.
On rainy days, he might not want to exert himself further, so he takes the elevator instead.
But the key here is that he only does this on rainy days.
So the reason must be related to the weather conditions.
The most logical reason is that walking up the stairs in the rain is uncomfortable or unsafe, so he takes the elevator all the way up.
Let me double-check: on normal days, he takes the elevator to the 15th floor and walks up.
On rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way.
So the difference is the weather.
Therefore, the reason is to avoid walking in the rain, which is either uncomfortable or potentially dangerous.
I think that's the main reason.
It's about the inconvenience or hazard of walking in the rain.

</think>

The man takes the elevator all the way up to the 30th floor on rainy days because walking up the stairs from the 15th floor would be slippery and uncomfortable in the rain.
This makes the elevator a safer and drier option.
